articles.headline: Administration Is Near Finance Overhaul Plan
articles.snippet: A comprehensive regulatory plan for the financial industry is expected to go to Congress this summer.
articles.abstract: A comprehensive regulatory plan for the financial industry is expected to go to Congress this summer.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Washington is asking some painful questions about how to prevent the next financial meltdown. Should it reinvent the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation? Abolish the seemingly feckless overseer of savings and loans? Grant new powers to the Federal Reserve?

articles.headline: Banks May Soon Get Approval to Leave the Bailout Program
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve plans to announce next week an “initial set” of banks that can repay government support, and escape the restrictions that came with it.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve plans to announce next week an “initial set” of banks that can repay government support, and escape the restrictions that came with it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since the government pressed billions of dollars in taxpayer support on the nation’s banks, several strong institutions have been pushing to give it back. Now a few of them may get the go-ahead next week  a crucial step in disentangling themselves from Washington.

articles.headline: Israel and U.S. Can’t Close Split on Settlements
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is facing pressures in Israel and with the U.S. over West Bank settlements.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is facing pressures in Israel and with the U.S. over West Bank settlements.
articles.lead_paragraph: KFAR TAPUAH, West Bank  Thirty Israeli couples are on a waiting list to move into the Kfar Tapuah settlement, which teems with children on the hilltops south of Nablus. Some on the list grew up here. But there is not an apartment available for sale or rent, or even a stifling trailer to be had.

articles.headline: G.M.’s New Owners, U.S. and Labor, Adjust to Roles
articles.snippet: Life has become more complicated for the United Automobile Workers union, a sometime antagonist and now a major shareholder.
articles.abstract: Life has become more complicated for the United Automobile Workers union, a sometime antagonist and now a major shareholder.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, the United Automobile Workers had a simple strategy for getting what it wanted from the carmakers  it would go on strike. The tactic proved so successful that the mere threat of a walkout often won better wages, benefits and job security.

articles.headline: Obama’s Test: Restoring G.M. at Arm’s Length
articles.snippet: The longer the government holds on to its stake in General Motors, the more the pressures will build to intervene in its business.
articles.abstract: The longer the government holds on to its stake in General Motors, the more the pressures will build to intervene in its business.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama boiled down his three goals as the reluctant majority shareholder of General Motors this way on Monday: “To get G.M. back on its feet, take a hands-off approach and get out quickly.”

articles.headline: For G.M. Chief, Little Time and a Full Plate
articles.snippet: Fritz Henderson, a relative unknown in corporate America, has only a few months to turn General Motors around.
articles.abstract: Fritz Henderson, a relative unknown in corporate America, has only a few months to turn General Motors around.
articles.lead_paragraph: Generations of business leaders around the world were schooled in the principles of management devised in the 1920s by General Motors’ president, Alfred P. Sloan Jr.

articles.headline: Cigarettes Without Smoke, or Regulation
articles.snippet: That electronic cigarettes are unapproved by the government and virtually unstudied has not deterred thousands of smokers from buying them.
articles.abstract: That electronic cigarettes are unapproved by the government and virtually unstudied has not deterred thousands of smokers from buying them.
articles.lead_paragraph: FALL RIVER, Mass.  During 34 years of smoking, Carolyn Smeaton has tried countless ways to reduce her three-pack-a-day habit, including a nicotine patch, nicotine gum and a prescription drug. But stop-smoking aids always failed her.

articles.headline: North Korean Leader Is Said to Pick a Son as Heir
articles.snippet: Kim Jong-il has apparently chosen Kim Jong-un, his youngest son, to succeed him as North Korea’s leader, South Korea’s main intelligence agency said.
articles.abstract: Kim Jong-il has apparently chosen Kim Jong-un, his youngest son, to succeed him as North Korea’s leader, South Korea’s main intelligence agency said.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by David E. Sanger, Mark Mazzetti and Choe Sang-hun and written by Mr. Sanger.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Mark Mazzetti and Choe Sang-Hun
